content.title: Cafezique, modern food with Mediterranean inspiration

introduction.small: Located in Glasgow's West End, Cafezique is a trendy place open all day for coffee or a meal.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Cafezique, modern food with Mediterranean inspiration

paragraphs.text:
Out of Glasgow's tourist loops, Cafezique is well worth the detour. In an old-fashioned building that used to house a dairy producer, this restaurant plays the romantic card. Looking like an English cottage, it reveals a shabby-chic interior design, storing bargain-hunted items and eclectic pieces of aged furniture. The stone walls and period wooden floors have been kept. Colourful crockery has been laid on rustic-looking tables, watched over by large black-and-white serigraphs.
Food lovers rush to Cafezique all day long, from breakfast to dinner, and revel in Mediterranean-influenced cuisine prepared with local products. For brunch, the menu goes English all the way (with a vegetarian option), serving a wide variety of eggs. At night, select a few tapas (hummus, olives, toast…) or more substantial food like a marrow risotto with goat cheese. Healthy food that will set the palate astir.

Cafezique
66 Hyndland St
Glasgow G11 5PT

+44 141 339 7180

www.cafezique.com

Menu: around 18 GBP

content.title: The Gannet, refined traditional Scottish cuisine

introduction.small: In Glasgow, The Gannet is part of the new food scene and offers a high end menu that sublimates traditional Scottish recipes.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Gannet, refined traditional Scottish cuisine

paragraphs.text:
The Finnieston neighbourhood is considered to be the new meeting point in Glasgow for food lovers looking for a refined experience. The Gannet happens to be just that, with its Scottish cuisine in turmoil. The restaurant bets on a modern take of traditional regional recipes, and aims at the greatest product quality and traceability. There, the relationship between chefs and local suppliers has been the key to success. In a 1980s industrial style, corrugated iron partly covers the walls and a rustic feel is conveyed by the constant use of wood and exposed stone in the design. A few oil paintings depicting the British countryside add to the local quirk. The Gannet pays tribute to the Scottish culinary heritage, as the menu changes seasonally and depending on deliveries. Perthshire pigeon, Shetland hake and St Brides free range chicken are some of your options… Discover a totally updated local gastronomy!

The Gannet
1155 Argyle Street
Glasgow G3 8TB

+44 141 204 2081

www.thegannetgla.com ﻿

Menu: around 29 GBP

content.title: The 78, paradise for vegetarians

introduction.small: Vegetarians have their headquarters in Glasgow: The 78. A restaurant with incomparable energy that is always abuzz.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The 78, paradise for vegetarians

paragraphs.text:
A 10-minute walk from the Kelvingrove Museum, The 78 is a haven for vegetarians. The decor looks like a welcoming country house with wooden tables paired with mismatched vintage chairs. On one side of the room, the open kitchen allows you to watch the chef at work. On the other, you can enjoy the fireplace that warms you on cold days. The setting creates a convivial and soothing atmosphere.

The restaurant menu is limited, but delicious and very affordable. Try the Classic 78 Burger, served with paprika coleslaw, or falafel wraps with hummus. The bar also offers a nice selection of beers.

On weekends, DJs take over to make you dance until late at night and Wednesday night is open mike night. The 78 is a popular Glasgow address, so make sure you reserve a table!

The 78
10-14 Kelvinhaugh Street
Glasgow G3 8NU

+44 141 576 5018

www.the78cafebar.com

Menu: around 10 GBP

content.title: Malmaison Glasgow, where you can sleep in a converted church

introduction.small: Sleeping in an Orthodox church, that's a bit out of the ordinary. The Malmaison Glasgow has met the challenge and brought this building up to date.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Malmaison Glasgow, where you can sleep in a converted church

paragraphs.text:
In the centre of the city, Malmaison Glasgow is an unusual place to spend the night, offering 72 rooms in a Greek Orthodox church that dates back to the 1830s. You may actually feel like in heaven! Some rooms are on the small size as they are using the existing spaces of the church, but you have several options and they all are decorated with eclectic taste. In a very contemporary style, they are dressed in grey and taupe hues contrasting with bright coloured cushions and sheets, paired with modern art on the walls.
The hotel houses a restaurant and a bar, both called “Chez Mal”. You can eat at this brasserie for creative and surprising cuisine, and end the night at the bar section for a glass of wine or a cocktail with your beloved.

Malmaison Glasgow
278 West George street
Glasgow G2 4LL

+44 121 456 8613

www.malmaison.com

Rooms: from 95 GBP

content.title: Glasgow and the shopping spree

introduction.small: In the United Kingdom, Glasgow ranks 2nd right after London for shopping addicts. From renowned brands to confidential designers, the choice is huge.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Glasgow and the shopping spree

paragraphs.text:
Style Mile is a very classy pedestrian area and the main shopping street in the city, between Buchanan Street, Argyle Street and Merchant City. This is where you will find all the best luxury shops. But not only. For there are two malls in Buchanan Street with brands and shops accessible to everyone.
If you want to find that rare gem you could bring back from your trip, head for the West End and stroll around vintage shops and other trendy second-hand clothes shops. But if you didn't find it, keep on Great Western Road or Ingram Street and enter the various small designer and fashion shops. If you have some more time on your hands, saunter through Merchant City, temple of design. Good shopping spree!

www.visitbritain.com/fr/fr/style-mile

www.glasgowstylemileshoppingfestival.com

content.title: The Corinthian Club, « the place to be »

introduction.small: The previous Commercial Court has been transformed into a trendy party spot, which resonates all night long.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Corinthian Club, « the place to be »

paragraphs.text:
Welcome to this 19th-century palace with its splendidly decorated five-storeys adorned with elegant mouldings, columns and mosaics. At Corinthian Club, you are standing in what was once Glasgow's Commercial Court. A restaurant, bar and nightclub all in one, it also boasts a casino. Each floor is uniquely decorated and serves a different purpose, with a multitude of small private spaces to get away or hold a quiet conversation.

Corinthian Club offers a variety of experiences: depending on your time of arrival and wishes, you can have a seat at the restaurant-brewery under the large multiple-faced stained glass dome to enjoy an original and creative speciality. The bar offers a cosy and elegant atmosphere to sip cocktails while listening to a jazz musician or a DJ behind his console.

On a lower level, the dance floor, in a chic theatre décor, is in full swing until the break of dawn while the casino's roulette–and one's savings–are spinning out of control. The stage's curtain is never lowered at Corinthian Club.

The Corinthian Club
191 Ingram Street
Merchant City
Glasgow G1 1DA

+44 141 552 1101

www.thecorinthianclub.co.uk

Menu: around 21 GBP

content.title: Blythswood Square Hotel, chic and cosy

introduction.small: Located in an elegant Victorian home only a few minutes from the city centre, this boutique hotel dares mixing classic and modern tones.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Blythswood Square Hotel, chic and cosy

paragraphs.text:
In front of the Blythswood Square green lawn, this magnificent 19th century building stands like a palace. Once the headquarters of the Royal Scottish Automobile Club, it now houses a five-star hotel that offers its luxury-craving clientele about a hundred rooms. Over this rather classical – almost aristocratic backdrop, the decoration is modern, mixing contemporary elements with finely crafted high ceilings and colonnades.
In the bedrooms, designer ceiling lights harmoniously match with woolly fabrics and padded headboards. The restaurant displays the same off-the-wall atmosphere with a decoration that plays on brownish hues with slight touches of purple, while at the bar grey tartans mix with white marble. In all the private areas of the hotel, most notably the screening room, armchairs are covered in colourful tartan fabric. Finally, you'll take advantage of the spa, its nine luxury treatment rooms and the beautiful swimming pool, as they are soaked in a very refined atmosphere, favourable for relaxation.

Blythswood Square Hotel
11 Blythswood Square
Glasgow G2 4AD

+44 141 248 8888

www.townhousecompany.com/blythswoodsquare/

Rooms: from 140 GBP

content.title: Dakota Deluxe favors an industrial style

introduction.small: Inaugurated in 2016, this chic and contemporary hotel is located in an old industrial building. It is the latest place in vogue in Glasgow.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Dakota Deluxe favors an industrial style

paragraphs.text:
In the middle of the city centre red brick buildings, this former warehouse has been dressed in black: the Dakota Deluxe cuts a fine figure, with 83 rooms and suites in a cocooning atmosphere. Inside, the New-York industrial style works like a charm with a skilful mixture of bricks, wood, leather and shimmering textures.
The grill restaurant offers an inventive cuisine based on first-choice local products. More intimate, the bar exhibits a fine cocktail list and even has a champagne room at your disposal, which is always a great success.
In the hallways dressed in warm hues and dim lights, you will find some book alcoves that guests are free to sift through before going back to their intense grey cocoon rooms. From the furniture to the fabrics, through elegant engravings around the bed, everything is in total harmony. The night will be tender

Dakota Deluxe Hotel Glasgow
179 West Regent Street
Glasgow G2 4DP

+44 141 404 3680

www.glasgow.dakotahotels.co.uk

Rooms: from 125 GBP

content.title: Cafe Gandolfi, “arty” ambiance with Scottish flavours

introduction.small: One of the oldest cafes in the city and the ideal place to have a drink, eat breakfast, lunch or dinner or enjoy a weekend brunch.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Cafe Gandolfi, “arty” ambiance with Scottish flavours

paragraphs.text:
Cafe Gandolfi was conceived 30 years ago by designer Tim Stead, an alumnus of Glasgow School of Art, and has been left untouched. With tables and chairs sculpted out of raw wood, the cafe part of the ground floor has a rustic setting with an arty and poetic touch, and opens at breakfast time. A level above, under the building's roof, there is a bar area with a more bistro-style ambiance.

Whether on the ground level or 1st floor the menu stays the same, with the exception of pizza, which is only available at the bar. The menu contains traditional Scottish dishes such as haggis, smoked fish and their famous pudding. Just next door, from 84 to 86 Albion Street, the owners opened an excellence seafood restaurant, le Gandolfi Fish, which offers fish and shellfish fished and smoked in the region.

Cafe Gandolfi
64 Albion Street
Glasgow G1 1NY

+44 141 552 6813

www.cafegandolfi.com

Menu: around 19 GBP

content.title: Sweet life at Grasshoppers Hotel

introduction.small: Near Glasgow Central Station, the small, trendy and inexpensive hotel enjoys perfect location and a fantastic view onto the city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Sweet life at Grasshoppers Hotel

paragraphs.text:
From the street, no one would believe that this large stone building near Glasgow Central Station is in fact a nice, chic hotel… And yet, you just have to take the lift up to the 6th floor to discover this lovely nest with a view onto the city. In a Scandinavian spirit, each of the 30 rooms displays a different look, on a background of coloured wallpapers. Whether king sized or twinned, the bedding is adaptable and the sheets made out of Egyptian cotton.
After a night of pleasant dreaming, make room for a Scottish breakfast of genuine flavours. It is served at your will either in the dining room or in your bedroom. Each morning, the menu varies, depending on the daily pickups: eggs, bacon, fruits, dairies, porridge, cheese... and baskets full of pastries!

Grasshoppers Hotel Glasgow
87 Union Street
Glasgow G1 3TA

+44 141 222 2666

www.grasshoppersglasgow.com

Rooms: from 67 GBP

content.title: Glasgow Cathedral, Gothic masterpiece

introduction.small: This cathedral is the only church of Scotland that survived the Protestant Reformation of 1560. Its architecture, exceptional stained-glass windows and neighbouring cemetery all are worth a look.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Glasgow Cathedral, Gothic masterpiece

paragraphs.text:
Construction work began in the 12th century and ended in the 15th. This gothic building is not only one of the most famous of all Scotland, but also the last of its kind, all the others having been destroyed during the Protestant reformation in the 16th century. Legend has it that Saint Mungo, Glasgow's patron saint, is buried underneath. Incidentally, you can visit the crypt where lies the tomb of this Medieval hero, whose coat of arms is made of four emblems telling his miracles: a robin that Mungo is said to have revived; a tree which branches were used to keep a fire alive; a bell brought back from Rome used to mourn the deceased; and a fish with a ring in its mouth, a reference to the legend of Queen Languoreth of Strathclyde.

In the building, architecture enthusiasts will enjoy the beautiful archways and vaulted alleyways. You may be stunned by the Millennium Window, the most recent stained-glass window of the cathedral. Revealed in 1999 to celebrate the past Millennium, it is a symbol of progress that stages scenes from the Bible. When you get out, do not forget to talk a walk among the tombstones in the little Victorian cemetery, final resting place for many of the city's public figures.

Glasgow Cathedral
Castle Street
Glasgow G4 0QZ

+44 141 552 8198

www.glasgowcathedral.org.uk

content.title: CitizenM, designer and digital hotel

introduction.small: The favourite hotel of those who go down to basics. Design setting, original decoration and high tech devices. With very competitive prices.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: CitizenM, designer and digital hotel

paragraphs.text:
Trendy Glaswegian hot spot, CitizenM is located in a modern building of the theatre district, between Renfrew Street and Hope Street. The glass façade and welcoming entrance are enticing. This is the world of CitizenM, a hotel concept straight from the Netherlands which principle is to make design more accessible while offering every establishment a high-end decoration designed by the world's greatest designers.

Your booking confirmation in hand, you don't have to wait in the lobby since your register yourself electronically. Fear not, in case you need anything, a hostess will offer to help.
At CitizenM, all bedrooms are the same. No twins, only king sizes with the best bedding available. Another characteristic, technology is the best there currently is, with tablets available for anyone and multicoloured LED lighting in the showers. On ground floor, the restaurant and bar are the trendiest you can find in all Glasgow.

CitizenM Glasgow
60 Renfrew Street
Glasgow G2 3BW

+44 20 3519 1111

www.citizenm.com/destinations/glasgow/glasgow-hotel

Rooms: from 85 GBP

content.title: Go see a play for lunch

introduction.small: Indulge in A Play, a Pie and a Pint at Òran Mór, an unusual concept in an uncommon location that welcomes shows, concerts and plays.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Go see a play for lunch

paragraphs.text:
A true institution in Glasgow, Òran Mór is an old church turned into a pub, bar and theatre. With black painted walls, raw timber and glass windows, the “modern-gothic” decoration fits this unique location well. At lunchtime, Glaswegians are fond of a very special event: A Play, a Pie and a Pint. The plays cover many different genres – tragedies, comedies, monologues, musicals – and stage the works of famous British playwrights as well as upcoming talents.
This original programming offers shows between 30 and 50 minutes. Just the time for you to enjoy your pie, quench your thirst and educate yourself! Of course, the price includes both performance and lunch. It is strongly recommended to book in advance.

Òran Mór
Byres Road
Glasgow G12 8QX

+44 141 357 6200

www.oran-mor.co.uk/

content.title: A visit of the massive Campus

introduction.small: Founded in 1451, the University of Glasgow is the fourth most ancient in the English-speaking world. Its architecture, nonstandard dimensions and list of teachers will make you dizzy.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A visit of the massive Campus

paragraphs.text:
The University of Glasgow is the spitting image of the Hogwarts School in the Harry Potter book series. Built in stone and of huge proportions, the elegant premises have been designed around several buildings linked by courtyards and long vaulted corridors. The roofs and turrets are subtle and finely crafted, and the bell tower is visible for miles around. This gothic style construct is the pride and joy of Glasgow, very high in the ranking of universities around the world. Among the alumni, you can count several Nobel prize winners and famous teachers like Adam Smith, James Watt and Albert Einstein.

The campus shelters several museums, including the Hunterian Museum which houses a collection of fossils, ancient tools and scientific instruments, as well as the Zoology Museum, rich in collections of insects, corals and stuffed animals. Also of interest is the Anatomy Museum, showing body parts preserved in formaldehyde (by appointment only). However, this one is not for the faint of heart!

Glasgow University
University Avenue
Glasgow G12 8QQ

+44 141 330 2000

www.gla.ac.uk

content.title: Hutchesons, above all, a haven for carnivores

introduction.small: If you love meat and unusual places, this is a must-try! If you prefer fish, rest assured the product quality is just as good!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hutchesons, above all, a haven for carnivores

paragraphs.text:
Inside a 17th century-listed building, this spot is well worth a detour to visit. A former hospital, it was later transformed into a library then a bank. It is now Hutchesons' Hall, which offers a bar on the ground floor and a restaurant on part of the first floor. Before being seated, admire the genuine period high ceilings with sculpted mouldings and stained glass–a true masterpiece. Then discover a selective menu boasting local products from small producers.

For those with a large appetite, the well-known Chateaubriand is a hit–served for two, it weighs at least 1kg!–as well as the famous prime rib. You may also indulge in the must-try smoked salmon or sole meunière. You will find a very trendy bar on ground floor, with its ambiance as surprising as its cocktails, notably The Big Smoke, a Cherrywood Smoked Jameson Whisky, Lapsang Souchong and bitters-based beverage served in a misty manner, surrounded by a halo of smoke. A wonderful evening!

Hutchesons' Hall
158 Ingram Street
Glasgow G1 1EJ

+44 141 552 4050

www.hutchesonsglasgow.com

Menu: around 19 GBP

content.title: Fall back into childhood at the Sharmanka Kinetic Gallery & Theatre

introduction.small: Venture into a world of marvel filled with fun and charming characters.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Fall back into childhood at the Sharmanka Kinetic Gallery & Theatre

paragraphs.text:
Set amid the art and creativity centre called Trongate 103, this extraordinary mechanical theatre was created in 1989 in St. Petersburg and moved to Glasgow in 1996 by Russian sculptor and mechanic Eduard Bersudsky. It consists of hundreds of small kinetic sculptures nicknamed kinemats by the artist and made out of recycled material. The Sharmanka Kinetic Gallery & Theatre is one of these places, magical and bewitching, where one loves to fall back into childhood.
Every hour, kinemats come alive in an enchanting choreography livened up by lighting and music. The show is at once fun and tragic, telling the story of how man tries to escape the circle of life and death. The Sharmanka has become of the city's hidden gems and will offer you a unique moment of sharing, based on pleasure and emotion. Very recommended as family outing.

Sharmanka Kinetic Gallery & Theatre
Trongate 103
Glasgow G1 5HD

+44 141 552 7080

www.sharmanka.com/Home

content.title: Ubiquitous Chip, a must-try

introduction.small: The best address to savour refined and modern Scottish cuisine. Brewery or tasting menu, the choice is yours.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Ubiquitous Chip, a must-try

paragraphs.text:
Open since 1971, this restaurant is a delight for Glaswegians food lovers and keeps on acquiring awards. Located in former stables on Ashton Lane, a small, charming and lively cobblestone street, the place includes several areas, each with a different ambiance in which the chef serves his best cuisine. You can enjoy a menu that changes seasonally, always including the famous and exquisite Aberdeen beef tenderloin on the ground floor in an inner courtyard with an urban jungle-like setting.

Both more relaxed and less expensive, the brewery located on the first floor has mezzanine or terrace seating areas where you can enjoy traditional Scottish dishes such as tuna tartar, smoked salmon or the famous stuffed ewe's stomach, prepared with both savoir-faire and originality. The wine list is as selective as the whiskey list, to taste at the cocktail bar (with moderation, of course), the best being the Island of Islay's very peaty product.

Ubiquitous Chip
12 Ashton Lane
Glasgow G12 8SJ

+44 141 334 5007

www.ubiquitouschip.co.uk

Menu: around 36 GBP

content.title: Stravaigin, organic cuisine with a marriage of Asian flavours

introduction.small: Scottish specialities are revisited with a Thai influence, offering an array of flavours to be discovered.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Stravaigin, organic cuisine with a marriage of Asian flavours

paragraphs.text:
This ‘slow food' address is known in all of Glasgow by word of mouth. Located in the basement of a pub offering a wide array of Scottish and foreign beers to taste without the slightest hesitation–especially the 1488 Premium Whisky Beer, brewed in Scotland. Simply borrow a ladder to dive into a simple and warm atmosphere with the sole criterion “Think Global, Eat Local”. As in many other restaurants in the city, you will only find fresh, local and seasonal products selected only from the best producers.

The chef loves to surprise with innovative cuisine rich in spices and daring combinations. The organic salmon filet is served with a coriander chilli puree and the grilled mackerel with black beans, but you may set your heart on the sea bream fillet with cauliflower salad. The dessert menu has not been forgotten, with a hot nut pie. One thing is certain, you will not leave hungry!

Stravaigin
28 Gibson Street
Glasgow G12 8NX

+44 141 334 2665

www.stravaigin.co.uk

Menu: around 28 GBP

content.title: Picnic at Loch Lomond

introduction.small: Loch Lomond National Park is less than an hour drive from Glasgow and offers a spectacular landscape.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Picnic at Loch Lomond

paragraphs.text:
Enjoy the Scottish countryside and breath the Highlands air on the shores of Loch Lomond. This great lake surrounded by mountains is the largest Scottish loch and the most widespread inland water source of the United Kingdom, with a size of 71 km2 (27 mile2) This is where Glaswegians go to clear their minds on weekends, enjoying many water sports and activities, among which speed boat trips.

In wintertime, stunning walks are aplenty in Loch Lomond and the Trossachs National Park. Besides the lake itself, it counts 21 munros, 3,000 feet high mountains. You will fall for the charm of this spectacular landscape comprised of rocks, forests and moors, all giving intense and surreal colouring to this majestic site. If you are careful, you may be able to catch a glimpse of red squirrels, otters and even better, golden eagles.

www.lochlomond-trossachs.org

content.title: Free entry to Kelvingrove Museum

introduction.small: Kelvingrove Art Gallery and Museum is one of the largest free museums in the United Kingdom. It gathers 22 galleries where many artistic and historic items are on display.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Free entry to Kelvingrove Museum

paragraphs.text:
Open to the public since 1901, this massive red sandstone building of Spanish Baroque style gathers a collection of 8,000 items, each one more incredible than the last. Varied items, ceramics, armours, sculptures, as well as paintings divided by themes over three floors. Such variety is sure to please children and adults alike, as usually is the case in the ancient costumes, armours and weapons rooms. Archaeological treasures figure prominently, especially those of Antique Greece and Egypt, and you will be able to gaze at a truly beautiful Egyptian sarcophagus.

Further down the museum, enjoy a natural history lesson with a collection of insects and stuffed mammals. The last floor contains works by European artists, most notably French Impressionists, and Scottish Colourists. Do not miss such masterpieces as Dali's Christ of St John of the Cross or Botticelli's Annunciation. Temporary exhibitions take place on the ground floor, and they are worth your time too.

The Kelvingrove Art Gallery and Museum
Argyle Street
Glasgow G3 8AG

+44 141 276 9599

www.glasgowlife.org.uk/museums/kelvingrove/Pages/default.aspx

content.title: Promenade at Pollok Country Park to admire the Burrell Collection

introduction.small: Far from the urban turmoil, amid the Pollok Country Park, this museum gathers millionaire Sir William Burrell's art collection, bequest to the city of Glasgow in 1944.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Promenade at Pollok Country Park to admire the Burrell Collection

paragraphs.text:
A 15-minutes drive from the centre of Glasgow, the Pollok Country Park invites you to a journey through time and civilisations. The first work you will admire is the museum in itself. Built in 1970 by English architect Garry Basson, it plays the card of transparency. This modern building of glass and bricks lies at the centre of an immense lawn. Each room is bathed in light and highlights the sumptuous Burrell collection, full of Egyptian sculptures, Chinese ceramics and jewels from Ancient Greece.

Wander with delight through the Hutton room, a reconstruction of the inner rooms of William Burrell's castle decorated in both gothic and baroque styles. Stop at the spaces devoted to 19th and 20th centuries' artists, where you'll find works by Degas and Cézanne – regarding the latter, you should not miss the Chateau de Medan. You will also have multiple occasions to admire Rodin's sculptures, in particular a version of his Thinker.

Burrell Collection
Pollok Country Park
2060 Pollokshaws Road
Glasgow G43 1AT

+44 141 287 2550

www.glasgowlife.org.uk/museums/burrell-collection

content.title: 15 Glasgow, a very charming address

introduction.small: Set in a Victorian house near the botanical garden, this 5-room boutique B&B is a romantic stopover in a lively neighbourhood.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: 15 Glasgow, a very charming address

paragraphs.text:
A stone's throw away from the city centre, this little known address is a true safe haven. A typical 1830s house with perron and two floors, it consists of three regular rooms and two suites all stylishly decorated, suffused with poetry and feminine touches.
Particularly cosy, the two suites offer a view onto the back garden. The Blue one has a living room area and is drenched in skies and seas overtones. The other is on first floor, displays pinkish hues and pays tribute to Charles Rennie Mackintosh, the most famous of Glaswegians. You'll discover Art Deco furniture in the suite, including a replica of a chair designed by the major Scottish architect and designer.
The three regular rooms are in the same cocooning spirit. Do not look for a breakfast dining room as there is none, for breakfast is served at your convenience directly in your room, a custom service courtesy of the owners Lorraine and Anthony. Furthermore, the dynamic and smiling couple will happily share a few tips with you – what are the best and closest places to eat for instance.

15 Glasgow
15 Woodside Place
Glasgow G3 7QL

+44 141 332 1263

www.15glasgow.com

Rooms: from 90 GBP

content.title: Riverside Museum in Glasgow, unifying land and sea

introduction.small: Named after its location along the Clyde River, this gorgeous new building was designed by architect Zaha Hadid. It houses the transportation museum.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Riverside Museum in Glasgow, unifying land and sea

paragraphs.text:
Built in 2011 on the site of an old shipyard, the building shines and exudes modernity and complexity, crowned by two-hundred tons zinc-titanium mirroring structure. Turned towards the water along the Clyde River, the façade evokes for some an EEG and for others breaking waves.
Inside, the museum endeavours to give a summary of land-based transportation. Skateboards stand alongside a steam locomotive, a tram or an 1898 subway car. The collection also puts on display a series of vehicles built in Scotland, from automobiles and bicycles to motorbikes and even a hearse.
After inland transportation, you'll move on to the sea section. On board the Glenlee, a wondrous 19th century cargo ship berthed along the museum, various items, photographs and documents tell the life of sailors at sea. An impressive collection for a breathtaking setting.

Riverside Museum
100 Pointhouse Road
Glasgow G3 8RS

+44 141 287 2720

www.glasgowlife.org.uk/museums/riverside/pages/default.aspx

content.title: On weekends, walk around Glasgow's flea market

introduction.small: Vendors at Barras Market offer various gems and amazing objects. It is one of the most colourful promenades in town.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: On weekends, walk around Glasgow's flea market

paragraphs.text:
The Barras was created in the interwar period by Margaret McIver, a young businesswoman eager to open barter in Glasgow's East End. Located in old Victorian buildings, the market now spreads over three large crowded streets. Every weekend, shoes, antiques, vinyl and second-hand clothes salesmen take over that hotchpotch of various items and psychedelic accessories that the place is world famous for. Assuredly, bargains await you.
As for food, the district is riddled with small tea rooms and genuine cafés that remain open during the entire weekend. You can also make a stop at the Barrowland Ballroom, located very nearby. It is one of the city's oldest venues, with a programme Glaswegians really look forward to.

Barras Market
Gallowgate
Glasgow G1 5AX

+44 141 552 4601

www.theglasgowbarras.com

content.title: Follow in architect Charles Rennie Mackintosh's footsteps

introduction.small: Artist, architect, and designer, this Glasgow native, a true artistic genius, gave birth to the Scottish Art Nouveau movement known as ‘Glasgow Style'.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Follow in architect Charles Rennie Mackintosh's footsteps

paragraphs.text:
One of Glasgow's most famous citizens is undoubtedly Charles Rennie Mackintosh (1868-1928), main figure of the Scottish Art Nouveau. Very much inspired by Japanese shapes and forms, the architect favoured a sober and practical style. Several of the buildings he designed are still visible in the city centre: the Mackintosh House, the Willow Tea Rooms and the Lighthouse – cultural centre devoted to design and architecture.
One of the first and most important creations of Charles Rennie Mackintosh yet remains the Glasgow School of Art. To make the best of your visit, do not miss the small library where everything, from the shelving to the dark wood chairs, is designed by Mackintosh. Discover an inimitable style, of high quality and fine crafting, making all things Mackintosh first order artistry.

Glasgow School of Art
167 Renfrew Street
Glasgow G3 6RQ

+44 141 353 4500

www.gsa.ac.uk
